channel.title: Stanford Solar Decathlon
channel.description: Sustainability at a push of a button

item.title: A New Beginning
item.dc:creator: derekouyang
item.content:encoded:
First we wanted to thank everybody who was involved in the proposal submittal process for Stanford Solar Decathlon 2013, which has been officially selected as one of twenty teams to compete in Orange County.
  • This includes the great folks at the Office of Sponsored Research and the SEQ who helped us with our paperwork and administrative process, and showed just how great Stanford is with helping students realize their goals.
  • This includes the faculty who, knowing how daunting of a challenge this project would be, embraced the motivation and passion of the students and agreed to support the team as PI’s or advisors.
  • This includes the companies and groups that proudly supported an initiative by Stanford students and provided a crucial promotion of our cause in the proposal and on campus.
  • And this includes the core, committed students who spent hours putting together a proposal that they felt captured the spirit of innovation at Stanford University, and the community of friends and family that supported them.
As first-time competitors we have a lot to do in terms of catching up to the more well-established teams in the competition, but that also means that we have an opportunity to bring something new to the table. We are looking forward to not only showing our mastery of the fundamentals of sustainable design, but also demonstrating some of the next-gen technology being developed in the Silicon Valley that will profoundly improve our comfort, productivity, creativity, and community in the home. If you are a student and would like to join the team, now is the best time! If you are an alumni or professional interested in engaging with the students on their design or supporting them through donations, now is the best time! Bookmark this website and check back regularly. Big things are about to happen! Best, Taylor Brady and Derek Ouyang Project Manager and Design Lead [image size="full"]http://solardecathlon.stanford.edu/wp-content/uploads/2012/02/derekandtaylor.jpg[/image]

item.title: Construction Team – Just Getting Started
item.dc:creator: mikemiller
item.content:encoded: The construction team has quickly been multiplying in the last couple weeks. We are currently made up of graduate students in the Construction Program, coming from the Sustainable Design and Construction (SDC), Construction Engineering and Management (CEM), and Design-Construction Integration (DCI) programs. The construction team will be working in several different capacities. We will not only be ultimately responsible for building the home in 2013 and transporting it to Orange County, but we will also play a significant role in the whole Solar Decathlon process. Possibly the most important responsibility will be to integrate the various sub-teams throughout the design process. This will be achieved through various multi-disciplinary design reviews, target value design, and an integrated and transparent scheduling process. One of the most critical tasks that was completed this week was to lay down a foundation for the overall project schedule. Milestones were first laid out based on DOE and project-initiated requirements. A high level schedule and course integration plan was laid on top to create this initial framework. To break this down into more detail, a liaison from the construction team to each sub-team has been identified and they will work with each team to educate them on pull scheduling strategies, build intermediate milestones, and track progress throughout the next two years. [image size="full"]http://solardecathlon.stanford.edu/wp-content/uploads/2012/05/project-schedule.jpeg[/image]

item.title: A Human-Informed Vision
item.dc:creator: jasonbade
item.content:encoded:
In designing and building a showcase house, it’s easy to get caught up making it cutting edge–filling it with the latest technology, employing the most modern design, making it as “smart” as it could possibly be. While all these elements may be cool or clever, they obscure our true vision, which is, simply, to build a home that satisfies human needs. Anything else is merely instrumental to that end.
[image size="medium" align="left"]http://solardecathlon.stanford.edu/wp-content/uploads/2012/05/300px-Cards_1.jpg[/image]An informal survey of most homes will reveal how poorly they achieve this objective. Considering the central role a home plays in the life of its inhabitants, its ability to contribute not only to their safety and security but also their health, happiness, and even life satisfaction is significant. Moreover, a large portion of our negative impact on our local and global communities stems from behaviors that take place in the home.
We can break down human needs into two broad categories–neither of which is mutually exclusive–which help us better conceptualize how various elements of the house’s design will more directly contribute toward our vision. We conceive of human needs as internal and external or, less abstractly, personal and global.
We define internal needs as those of people living in the house. Maslow’s hierarchy provides the nice visual metaphor of the pyramid for what we aim to achieve. Of course, the house will provide physical shelter by virtue of its roof, windows, and walls, warmth through insulation and heating, nourishment indirectly via the refrigerator and pantry, and of course water for bathing and drinking. But, as we ascend the hierarchy, a person’s needs become, admittedly, more difficult for a house to fulfill. Can a house help its inhabitants be healthier? Can it help them achieve their innate necessity to be social, to express themselves creatively, to have a sense of agency and control, to develop purpose and meaning in life? Perhaps a house can’t fulfill these (nor would we necessarily want it to), but it certainly can facilitate their attainment.
[image size="medium" align="right"]http://solardecathlon.stanford.edu/wp-content/uploads/2012/05/300px-Cards_2.jpg[/image]The second, external, set of needs are those of the community. Community broadly includes everyone from next-door neighbors to indigenous tribes halfway around the world as well as the larger ecosystems our actions affect. Through our house, our actions have impact on others. While that impact can be positive –just consider how diminished our capacity to contribute to the world would be if we didn’t have a comfortable place to rest every night–it is, unfortunately, negative in many domains. Here, we are most concerned with the rather large resource and waste footprint living, especially in the developed world, entails. A well-designed house not only runs itself more efficiently in terms of energy and water use as well as waste output, but it also guides its inhabitants toward making choices with less negative external cost on others, without imposing restrictions or limiting how much say one has over how she lives.
Behavioral design, as well as psychology in general, provides us with the tools to better realize both of these types of needs when combined with the already powerful abilities of architects and engineers. We are learning at a faster rate than ever before about both what makes people truly happy (oftentimes they don’t even know themselves!) and how we tend to behave, particularly in ways we neither suspect nor desire.

item.title: Summer @ Stanford!
item.dc:creator: derekouyang
item.content:encoded: The summer weather in Palo Alto couldn't be any better this week. While most of our team, being the Stanford students we are, have dispersed around the world or just started their internships at companies like Facebook, NVIDIA, and DPR Construction, about twenty of us are still right here on campus enjoying the sun and working on the one thing that has come to define our time at Stanford: designing the home of the future, Start.Home. We finished our Spring Quarter with a great team vision for how we will win the competition, along with great support from faculty and sponsors, and this summer we will be developing the models and documentation necessary to achieve 80% CD by October. Not to mention hitting the beach and cooking up BBQ every once in a while. Follow this blog and get updates week to week on the fun things we do, like educational workshops, Habitat for Humanity trips, conferences, house tours, and learning about both fundamental and innovative ideas in sustainable design. Also be sure to explore the rest of our website, as well as our news on Facebook and Twitter. Thank you for your support of Stanford Solar Decathlon, and have a fantastic summer! Derek Ouyang, Project Manager

item.title: Design Spotlight: MIMA House
item.dc:creator: laurabenard
item.content:encoded: Welcome to our inaugural "Design Spotlight" post.  Each Friday, we will be posting photos of products or houses that we admire or just think are super cool.  They say a picture is worth a thousand words, so we'll keep these posts text light and photo heavy. This week's spotlight is the famous MIMA House, designed by the firm Mima Architects, and located in Portugal.  According to ArchDaily, part of what makes this home so special is the fact that it "responds to the modern dream for clean sophisticated design and bright open spaces, launching in the housing market a dream 36 sqm dwelling which costs the same as a mid-range car."  Sounds pretty familiar!  To read more, check out this article.

item.title: Singapore Polytechnic CSDGC Youth Workshop
item.dc:creator: salvadoravila
item.content:encoded:
Solar Decathlon is a great way to get teams of people to work together; and it can be expanded to people of all ages not just college students. We hosted a youth workshop for a group of students from Singapore and taught them necessary skills to bring their dream homes to reality.

The day started off by introducing the students to the world of environmentally friendly homes. They were acquainted with the concepts and principles of what it truly meant for a home to be eco-friendly. Next, the students were randomly placed into teams and were challenged to design a home (with some Solar Decathlon constraints of course).

AND THEY'RE OFF! 58 jokes and 3478 ideas later the students began taking their poster board and launched their designs into reality. It was great to see that they not only absorbed the content about environmentally friendly homes from before, but they were also able to integrate a few ideas into their design's. After many laughs and (due to limited materials and time) scissor "borrowing" the students managed to get their small (albeit grand) homes together and see their ideas come to fruition. They ended their workshop by getting some lessons about how to use Google SketchUp to model their homes in a different way.

item.title: Student Spotlight: Derek Ouyang
item.dc:creator: laurabenard
item.content:encoded: Name: Derek Ouyang Hometown: Los Angeles Year: Senior Major: Civil Engineering & Architectural Design Position: Project Manager How did you get interested in sustainability, and how are you a sustainable leader in your community? When I was growing up, I had little idea how precious our natural resources were, especially in southern California where fresh water was in high demand. In middle school, I started attending outdoor science camps and environmental design classes, and it became apparent to me that my personal habits in water use, electricity use, and recycling could be seriously improved. In high school, I focused on gaining the science skills necessary to tackle the problem of sustainability from an engineering perspective, and in my first summer at Stanford I conducted research on plastic biocomposites that could be manufactured on a net-zero carbon cycle, and as part of that research grant I created sustainability courses and hands-on activities for the local junior museum. I think it starts with pushing yourself to lead a more sustainable lifestyle before you can inspire others to do the same. How did you get involved with Stanford Solar Decathlon? In Spring of 2011, fellow classmate Taylor Brady asked me if I was interested in helping him put together a proposal for Stanford to compete in the 2013 Solar Decathlon competition. Pretty quickly we assembled a team of students interested in pursuing this project for the first time, and in November we submitted a 30-page proposal with some of the earliest concepts of Start.Home. What has been your primary focus within the team? I started in a lead design role, helping to facilitate the formation of a team vision and approach to winning the competition. In Spring 2012 I switched to the project management role and focused on empowering every member of the team to successfully contribute to the project. I often attend meetings with faculty advisors and potential sponsors, as well as lead our team meetings. What has been your favorite part of Solar Decathlon thus far? My favorite part of the project has been meeting people at Stanford who share the same passion in sustainable design. When I first came to Stanford, I didn't know how many fellow architects, engineers, and designers I would find that wanted to devote their time to large building projects like Solar Decathlon. But when we first reached out to the community with this idea, it was amazing to see undergraduate, graduate, and PhD students from almost every engineering major answer back with enthusiasm. Nowadays I spent nearly all of my time working and hanging out with this team, and I couldn't have asked for a better group of friends. What are you most excited for in the remaining part of Solar Decathlon? Stanford, despite being a world leader in sustainable technologies, is a first time competitor in the Solar Decathlon. We have had to build everything from the very start through the dedication and motivation of students wanting to realize their vision of the future. Since then, a community of faculty members, mentors, and companies has joined our cause, and our innovative design is taking shape. I'm excited for finalizing our architectural plans, detailing our construction documentation, and communicating our vision through renders and videos. I'm really excited to actually build the house and show it off on Stanford campus. But I think I'm most excited to just go into the house in Irvine, after the competition is over, collapse on the bed, and sleep. Where do you see yourself in five years? I see myself starting an architectural practice in either California, New York, or possibly abroad that focuses on integration of architecture, engineering, and construction, as well as a commitment to sustainable design. I believe that out of my time at Stanford, the Solar Decathlon project will be the most valuable experience for my future career. How do you stay updated on emerging sustainable technologies? Do you have a favorite blog, columnist or site? In addition to ArchDaily for Dezeen sustainable design, The Sustainability tag on TED is an incredible collection of inspiring talks that everybody should watch! If you had one year to do anything you wanted (money was no issue), what would you do and why? After Stanford I plan to travel in Europe for a year and hop through countries like Slovenia, Germany, and Denmark, experiencing new cultures and meeting new people. Money will literally not be an issue because I'll be trying to live as sustainably as possible.

item.title: Habitat for Humanity
item.dc:creator: abahokatabarwa
item.content:encoded: One of the ways we're getting out of the design studios and testing labs at Stanford, learning more about construction, and lending a helping hand is by carpooling down to work at the Silicon Valley Habitat for Humanity build site in Cupertino, where the nonprofit organization is building four homes, each about the size of a Solar Decathlon home (1000 sqft). Our team had already gone once before a few months ago, when the wall frames were just getting started, and since seeing those photos I had been eagerly awaiting the next chance we'd get to build. When the chance came this week, Taylor and I, despite previous scheduling apprehensions, jumped at the opportunity to stretch our arms and legs. When we arrived, we were cordially invited on-site, pointed to a project leader, and given a brief overview of our task that day. Casually, the project leader told us we would be marking the areas on which the trusses would stand. A few moments later after some confusion, Taylor and I found ourselves pushing a heavy stack of trusses about twenty feet off the ground. It was a long agonizing process, but soon we had the stack in place and we proceeded to make the requested markings. We did not stick to one task all day. The project allowed us to be flexible and make ourselves available where we were needed. After the marking job, we found ourselves with a large group of Cisco employees and managers actually mounting trusses on one of the buildings. It was intimidating work. Personally, I had to get over my fear of heights and fast moving projectiles while confidently wielding a nail gun on a section of scaffolding. Although it seemed like a daunting task, we were surrounded by a group of capable and hardworking gentlemen (and one Stanford alum) who made the task seem trivial and at times hilarious. We broke off in the late afternoon, but not before telling our fellow workers about Solar Decathlon and what we hoped to accomplish this summer. They were visibly intrigued and supportive. Many offered words of  advice, encouragement, and even a few business cards. We left feeling more confident and having learned quite a bit. It was quite the constructive experience (pun intended).

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Hey Abaho,
Just wanted to say thanks for taking the time to write about your experience on site and spread the word. We posted a link on our new Habitat East Bay/Silicon Valley Facebook page. Check it out if you get a chance - Facebook.com/HabitatEBSV
Cheers! -Jeff

item.title: Say Goodbye to the Environmental Impacts of Styrofoam
item.dc:creator: stephaniezlateva
item.content:encoded:
We’ve all used Styrofoam, whether it be in the form of a take-away container, a cup, or some packaging material, but what many of us may not realize is that Styrofoam never truly goes away.  Often our used Styrofoam products are destined for landfills or improperly disposed of in the ocean, but two young engineers may have found an alternative.  Gavin McIntyre and Eben Bayer, co-founders of Ecovative in New York, have succeeded in creating a new, mushroom-based material similar to Styrofoam.  EcoCradle is completely biodegradable, safe, and environmentally-friendly. Here are some fast facts on the product: What is it? Organic Waste: Food scraps, seed husks, and other plants Mycelium: Mushrooms do not reproduce by seed, but by spores. When the spores reproduce, they produce single-celled, interwoven structures called hyphae (also known as Shiro). Together, the masses of hyphae are called Mycelium.   How is it made?
  1. The organic waste (agricultural waste) is cleaned using a steam heat process for sterilization. (Currently, McIntyre and Bayer are looking into replacing the steam-heat process with a treatment made from cinnamon-bark oil, thyme oil, oregano oil and lemongrass oil to decrease the energy required to sterilize the waste).
  2. This sterilized waste is then put in a container with growing Mycelium for about 5-10 days, until the desired Mycelium density is acquired. Since Mycelium is a mushroom and does not require photosynthesis, it grows in the dark at room temperature and without any water or petrochemicals.  As it grows, Mycelium acts as glue weaving between the organic waste, resulting in the desired structure. No energy is required for shaping the product because it is shaped as it grows into its plastic mold, which can be customized for preference.
  3. The final product is heat-treated to stop the spores from continuing from growing.
Why choose EcoCradle over Styrofoam?
  • EcoCradle is made using only one-eighth of the amount of energy Styrofoam uses in its manufacturing process and one-tenth the amount of carbon dioxide is released!
  • EcoCradle is:
    • fire resistant
    • moisture resistant
    • vapor resistant
    • hypoallergenic
  • EcoCradle decomposes within one month after it is buried in the ground.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Say Goodbye to the Environmental Impacts of Styrofoam
Ecovative Design’s biodegradable packaging is the new green alternative to Styrofoam.

item.title: Design Spotlight: Safe(R) House
item.dc:creator: laurabenard
item.content:encoded: This week’s home is designed by the Harvard Graduate School of Design in collaboration with the SENSEable City Laboratory at MIT.  A project initiated in response to the disastrous tsunami that struck South Asia in December of 2004, these researchers and designers strove to create Safe(R) House, a dwelling that would “resist the force of a tsunami as well as flooding.”  Built from locally available materials, Safe(R) House uses four main elements: “a raised platform to facilitate water drainage, concrete core structures that provide higher resistance without blocking the flow of water in case of incoming tsunami, bamboo or traditional woven partitions to create a porous or ventilated skin and a traditional roof structure made from coconut wood rafters and either tin roofing materials or tiles.”  Read more about this project here!

item.title: Dwell on Design: Modern Beyond Expectations
item.dc:creator: laurabenard
item.content:encoded: Going to Dwell Magazine's annual convention Dwell on Design was any designer's dream: 210,685 square feet of exhibits, presentations, and tours, and other programming.  Focusing on the theme of "modern beyond expectations," the festival was divided into various areas, such as Furniture & Accessories, Kitchen & Bath, or Dwell Outdoor.  Walking through the numerous aisles of exhibitors was similar to an overwhelming shopping trip for every home product you could ever want.  Every. Single. One. As our team is approaching the interior design stage, our team members had so much fun “shopping” for all of the products that could eventually be part of our Start.Home.  We spoke with several lighting representatives about their products, and fell in love with Lutron’s whole home lighting solutions.  It was incredible to see how so many of their systems were in direct alignment with our goal of the seamless integration of technology in the Start.Home.  Similarly, we saw great parallels with Cerno’s philosophy of accountability to both customer and environment through the integration of art and science. Though these are all fantastic and useful products, our overall favorite product was the Heliodisplay by IO2 Technology.  Let’s be real - who wouldn’t want a holographic display in their dream home?  Dear Santa, all we want for Christmas is...

item.title: Student Spotlight: Rob Best
item.dc:creator: laurabenard
item.content:encoded: Name: Rob Best Hometown: West Hills, CA (A suburb of LA) Year: Masters/Ph.D. Position/Subteam: Construction Lead     How did you get interested in sustainability and how are you a sustainable leader in your community? I’ve always been a nature lover. From the time I was young, I would go camping and hiking with my family and was always outdoors. My brother and I also loved trips to the zoo and learning about animals whenever possible. In high school, my love of the outdoors led me to a club called Envirothon, which was a 5-person competition team in the areas of wildlife, aquatics, forestry, soils, and a current topic. My senior year, the current issue topic was climate change and the urban environment. After researching the perils and causes of climate change and spending a year considering possible solutions, I recognized that my passion was in finding novel ways of reducing community resource use. Through college, I took every opportunity to learn more about sustainability and how I as an engineer could make an impact in reducing our resource use. After college, before Stanford, I seized an opportunity to learn more through the Thomas J. Watson Fellowship, which allowed me to travel for a year to China, India, the UAE, England, and Germany and study green building codes and practices through interviews and policy analysis. In my community, this passion for sustainable engineering led me to a group called Engineers for a Sustainable World, of which I have been a member since 2007. At Harvey Mudd College, I served for a year as president of the group and led two trips to Kenya to design and install a solar-powered water pump and lighting system for a high school in a rural and destitute region. In my immediate community, I spearheaded a campaign to institute a yearly energy reduction competition among all 8 dorms at the school along with composting and water-saving initiatives. After my tenure at HMC, I have continued with ESW as the nationwide Projects Director helping other campuses set up similar efforts, manage their own projects, and make a bigger impact in their communities.   How did you get involved with Stanford Solar Decathlon? I became involved with Stanford Solar Decathlon in early February at the insistence of the former Construction Lead, Mike Miller. I had just finished leading Stanford’s competition team in the annual Associated Schools of Construction competition, and Mike approached me about joining Stanford Solar Decathlon. I had been aware of the project since the beginning, but had not joined because I knew if I did that I would be hooked and would pour all of my free time into working on the house. However, when I met with Mike and the other leaders of the team, I saw that I would be joining a group just as passionate as I who would doubtless become some of my best friends at Stanford through our shared interest and devotion to the team. It was an easy decision to say yes, and I’ve been grateful ever since to be a part of this team.   What has been your primary focus within the team? My primary focus has been on the construction side. As the Construction Lead, I have been most focused on providing constructability feedback to the architecture team and others within the project. As modularity is a big piece of the competition and the start.home philosophy, I have worked hard with my group to come up with realistic concepts of how to connect the pieces of the home and safely transport and reconstruct every detail. With my team, I have also helped create an estimate for the home and prepare some of the scheduling and logistical details. While I enjoy the construction side, it has been fun every now and then to break away from that a bit and dabble in mechanical and architectural design. It really helps totally understand the house and all its elements, and I know that understanding will serve me well when we actually have to build it in the future!   What has been your favorite part of Solar Decathlon thus far? My favorite part of the project has been the architectural design. This is the first time I will see a project of this size through from design to construction and display, and I was thrilled to be a part of the earliest architectural design process. Getting to sketch my ideas and see some of them carry through into the stage where we are now was fantastic. The creativity of all of our team members was inspiring and something that keeps me motivated within this team.   What are you most excited for in the remaining part of Solar Decathlon? Just as designing the home has been my favorite part so far, I am stoked for building the house. Getting to realize what we have been working on this whole year will be phenomenal, and I can’t wait to see the finished product. Sure there will be some challenges, but I know we will create a truly awesome building at the end.   If you were stranded on an island, what would be the one piece of technology you would want to bring with you from the Start.Home? Hmm...that’s a tough one because as a construction person, I’m inclined to count the modular house itself as a novel technology, but that seems like cheating! I think I would have to take solar panels with me. At least then I’d have power for my cell phone. I’m never without it, and at least that way, I could charge it and play games while I wait for rescue.   Where do you see yourself in five years? I’m a Ph.D. student, so I may still be here at Stanford in five years working hard toward that last paper or piece of my dissertation. Hopefully, however, I’ll have escaped academia and be working in a field related to building and development. I can definitely picture myself working for a firm designing or consulting on sustainable buildings, but I could just as easily be happy looking at community-scale resource use in urban planning initiatives.   How do you stay up-to-date on emerging energy-related technology? Do you have a favorite blog, columnist or website? I have to say that I’m not tied to one particular source over another. I use lots of RSS feeds that go straight to my phone and flip quickly through the latest news as I walk to and from class. In addition to that, I chat with colleagues and attend seminars (for which Stanford is the perfect environment) to stay up to date on the bleeding edge tech.   If you had one year to do anything you wanted (money was no issue), what would you do and why? I’m a bit spoiled on this one, as I got to design my own project for a year after undergraduate through the Fellowship I was offered. During that year, I spent my time traveling and interviewing architects and engineers about sustainable building design, guidelines, and policies. I think now if I were to spend a year on my own, I’d head back to Africa and work in the communities with which I am familiar to help residents develop a better understanding of sustainable development and building in their context. The personal connections I felt during my time in Kenya were unbelievable, and I would love to spend more time among those I now count as friends. To be sure I’d do a bit of traveling as well (I would love to visit the rainforests of Uganda, the deserts of Egypt, and the parks of South Africa), but I would mostly spend time working with the schools I know to help them become healthier and economically sustainable.

item.dc:creator: stephaniezlateva
item.content:encoded:
There are buildings made out of bricks, wood, stone and mud, but salt? That’s pretty uncommon, but Bolivia’s Palacio de Sal (Translated: Bolivia’s salt palace) is completely made out of salt! It’s built on the eastern edge of Salar de Uyuni, the world’s largest salt flat*, 350 km (220 mi) south of Bolivia’s capitol, La Paz. Its ceilings, walls, floors, beds, chairs, tables, couches and other furniture are entirely made out of salt!

The Palacio de Sal was originally built in 2007 for the purpose of housing the large amount of travelers to the Salar de Uyuni in southwest Bolivia, near the crest of the Andes Mountains. The first salt hotel built was from 1993-1995, in the center of the Salar de Uyuni. It was dismantled in 2002 due to its numerous sanitation problems which were even more difficult to manage because of the hotel’s location of the middle of the desert. Its location had required waste be collected manually and mismanagement had created environmental pollution. But the Palacio de Sal has overcome these problems with a strict sanitary system that complies with government regulations, including laws that prohibit licking the walls.

With furniture, walls, ceilings, and floors made out of a total of 1 million 35- cm(14 inch) salt blocks, the Palacio de Sal is fully functional with a spa, restaurant, bar, large common rooms, 16 private rooms, and bathrooms that look like igloos. The spa is currently undergoing renovations but it will have a dry sauna, whirlpool baths, steam room, and a saltwater pool. The hotel even has a 9-hole golf course with a hard salt surface, open from May through November.

This hotel has become so popular for tourists that there are increasingly more hotels and hostels* built out of salt in the Salar de Uyuni.

*A place where large amount salt has been left by the evaporation of salt water *a building that provides cheap food and lodging for a specific group of people such as students, workers, or travelers

item.title: Palacio de Sal
item.dc:creator: stephaniezlateva
item.content:encoded:
There are buildings made out of bricks, wood, stone and mud, but salt? That’s pretty uncommon, but Bolivia’s Palacio de Sal (Translated: Bolivia’s salt palace) is completely made out of salt! It’s built on the eastern edge of Salar de Uyuni, the world’s largest salt flat*, 350 km (220 mi) south of Bolivia’s capitol, La Paz. Its ceilings, walls, floors, beds, chairs, tables, couches and other furniture are entirely made out of salt!

The Palacio de Sal was originally built in 2007 for the purpose of housing the large amount of travelers to the Salar de Uyuni in southwest Bolivia, near the crest of the Andes Mountains. The first salt hotel built was from 1993-1995, in the center of the Salar de Uyuni. It was dismantled in 2002 due to its numerous sanitation problems which were even more difficult to manage because of the hotel’s location of the middle of the desert. Its location had required waste be collected manually and mismanagement had created environmental pollution. But the Palacio de Sal has overcome these problems with a strict sanitary system that complies with government regulations, including laws that prohibit licking the walls.

With furniture, walls, ceilings, and floors made out of a total of 1 million 35- cm(14 inch) salt blocks, the Palacio de Sal is fully functional with a spa, restaurant, bar, large common rooms, 16 private rooms, and bathrooms that look like igloos. The spa is currently undergoing renovations but it will have a dry sauna, whirlpool baths, steam room, and a saltwater pool. The hotel even has a 9-hole golf course with a hard salt surface, open from May through November.

This hotel has become so popular for tourists that there are increasingly more hotels and hostels* built out of salt in the Salar de Uyuni.

*A place where large amount salt has been left by the evaporation of salt water *a building that provides cheap food and lodging for a specific group of people such as students, workers, or travelers

item.title: Algae-Powered Chlorella Air Pods
item.dc:creator: stephaniezlateva
item.content:encoded:
From all the external things that humans depend on most , air will always come first on our list. Unlike food and water which we can go without for a couple of days, we need air to live; only a few breaths short could kill us. Every second, 310 kg (683 pounds) of toxic chemicals are released into our air, accumulating to about 10 million tons (over 21 billion pounds) of toxic chemicals added to our atmosphere each year. Twenty percent of these chemicals are carcinogens,meaning there are about 2 million cancer causing toxins floating around in our air! The increasing rate of pollution has led to a new crisis: the need of more oxygen in polluted urban countries. The first “oxygen bars” were invented in 1996 in Toronto, Canada. Today, though, there are more ways of bringing fresh air to people in polluted urban areas, such as Adam Miklosim’s portable algae-powered chlorella* pods that create fresh air oases by combining chlorella photosynthesis with oxygen therapy.

The pod utilizes a semi-transparent Teflon membrane to create a disconnected feel from the outside world through reducing noise and voices from outside of the pod. The pod is very comfortable for its occupants; it has rail-bound reclinable chairs placed around the middle and solar panels on top to support the artificial lightning inside the pod. The middle hole of the “doughnut” is used for décor light and for an attractive algae fountain of changing, moving green colors. The Algae containers are placed on the underside of the pod, with carbon filters separating them from the pod to filter the algae smell. In addition, the pod includes an air sluice chamber and a sliding outer door.

The Teflon texture outside of the dome hides the view of outside pollution while still allowing 75% efficient sunlight utilization. The pod includes a large quantity of photobioreactors with a series of transparent plastic tubes. Inside the photobioreactors are 5 cubic meters of algae that purify the air and produce oxygen.

This design is still in the prototype stage,but hopefully it will be out in the market soon to provide a pollution refuge in urban industrial countries.

*a type of green single-celled alga (genus chlorella) of both terrestrial and aquatic habitats.

item.title: Spray-On Battery
item.dc:creator: stephaniezlateva
item.content:encoded:
In today’s world, almost everyone uses lithium batteries. They are rechargeable, have one of the best energy densities, and no memory effect*. But with today’s gadgets becoming smaller, containing a variety of surfaces, and loops or bends, designers are having more and more trouble placing the batteries in a way that won’t interfere with the workings of the gadget. The major flaw of lithium batteries is that they contain a block of inflexible, non-resizable matter that holds the electrons that make the battery to work. That’s where the spray-on battery paint comes in. The spray-on battery paint developed by a team of Rice University researchers in Houston, Texas overcomes the major problem of batteries for designers designing small, irregularly surfaced gadgets. With the spray-on battery technology, you could have any size battery on a curved surface, rough surface or on different mediums such as tile, plastics, glass, metal or ceramics. In addition, spraying on a battery, which takes less than a minute, is much faster than building a conventional battery that can take more than a hundred times longer to make.

What makes up the spray-on battery paint?

Just like all batteries, the battery paint consists of a polymer separator between two current collectors; a cathode*and an anode*. One version of paint medium researchers used is lithium cobalt oxide for the cathode, lithium titanium oxide for the anode, and conductive single-walled nanotubes for the polymer separator. These layers are sprayed on top of each other with a conventional airbrush. Then they are heat-sealed to make them insensitive to moisture and to keep from pealing after time. After that, multiple spray-on batteries can be paired up with a solar battery to recharge them when needed.

How is this technology currently being improved?

Currently, painting the layers of the battery needs to be done in a dry, oxygen-free room. The team of Rice University researchers is looking into a way to make the battery in normal circumstances, so it can be used by anyone, anywhere.

For a full breakdown of the team’s study, visit June 28th’s edition of Nature Scientific Reports. * Memory effect means the battery loses a little bit of its maximum energy carrying capacity after each use *a cathode is the positively charged end of a battery *an anode is the negatively charged end of a battery

item.title: Design Spotlight: HOM
item.dc:creator: laurabenard
item.content:encoded: The designers and architects of KAA Design Group in Los Angeles have created HOM Escape in Style TM, a comprehensive new product line that features sustainability at all levels.   Between the zinc-coated heat-resistant roof and the fact that the HOM is pre-wired for solar power, KAA has clearly put a lot of thought into making the ideal green retreat.  Varying in size from 1,000 to 3,000 SF, these homes are 90% factory built, but entirely customizable.  Look for more information and photos at their website.

item.title: Student Spotlight: Jacob Schaffert
item.dc:creator: laurabenard
item.content:encoded: Name:  Jacob Schaffert Hometown:  Phoenix, Arizona Year:  2013 Postion/Subteam:  Architectural Team Lead, General Nuisance Spirit Animal?  Mahatma Gandhi       How did you get interested in sustainability and how are you a sustainable leader in your community? I started working on student projects related to sustainability during high school in Phoenix. I was the president of the school’s “green team,” that put on several earth day events and did research into sustainable design features for a new school building that got scrapped. I also worked on converting a gasoline powered golf cart to run on homemade biodiesel that I brewed with a friend.   How did you get involved with Stanford Solar Decathlon? The first week of Autumn Quarter 2011, Derek O. (Project manager, also goes by D-Rock-n-roll) asked me if I was interested in an intense student project. I ended up editing, commenting, and redrafting the initial proposal, as well as brainstorming design concepts with a couple other people. I quickly became the go-to sketchup and design guy for the project after we got the go-ahead from the DOE.   What has been your primary focus within the team? I have been doing a lot of the design pitching and initial home model creation. So far I have logged over 300 hours of sketchup time (well on my way to my sketchup-pilot license). Inherent to design is a lot of iteration and dead-ends, which can be a little frustrating at times for a team made mostly of non-architects. Currently I am working on converting the current scheme into a BIM and simultaneously researching cladding and interior finishes. Also I am gearing up to facilitate construction documentation and detailing. (phew! maybe even sleep!)   What has been your favorite part of Solar Decathlon thus far? Each time I finish a sketchup model, I get a real rush. I think, “this is the one, this scheme is fantastic.” I also really like the discussions that are sparked from divergent schemes or design decisions; I think it is great to be on a team where people care so deeply about the architectural feel of a space. Unlike construction, structural engineering, or electrical engineering, which are all pretty specialized, people tend to have an intuitive understanding of space and are all interested in the architectural realization of our home.   What are you most excited for in the remaining part of Solar Decathlon? I can’t wait to start detailing the interior. I am really excited about trying to create some unique, flexible furniture to complement the flexible and open spaces I have already programmed. I think that this home will be made well in the diagram, but great in the details.   If you were stranded on an island, what would be the one piece of technology you would want to bring with you from the Start.Home? … the home, obviously (am I missing something here?)   Where do you see yourself in five years? I see myself finishing my master’s degree in architecture and starting to log hours to become licensed. This process has cemented in my mind my interest and passion for architecture as a practice. The mentors have been really key here. Ultimately, I would like to run my own firm, but I am not going to get ahead of myself. I mean, five years ago I was in high school and I don’t think that I would have guessed that I would be doing the things that I am doing today.   How do you stay up-to-date on emerging energy-related technology? Do you have a favorite blog, columnist or website? I usually check Derek O.’s facebook page since I am usually too busy working on Solar Decathlon to check a ton of blogs.   If you had one year to do anything you wanted (money was no issue), what would you do and why? Reanimate/Zombify/Kidnap Ray Charles, Aretha Franklin, Duke Ellington, Herman Cain (sing in the style of Donna Summers), George Harrison, Harrison Ford (as Han Solo), Genghis Kahn, Jack Black (cause why not), and Russell Crow (as Master and Commander)  and storm the world with the greatest band ever, and then sleep, tons and tons of sleep.

item.title: STOP! Don't Throw Away Your Old Credit Cards Just Yet...
item.dc:creator: stephaniezlateva
item.content:encoded:
... paying for things is not the only purpose they could serve. With a touch of creativity, you can turn any old card into something cool and useful. According to MTV Company’s blog, “If half a million people throw away an old credit card, that would make nearly 12,000 pounds of plastic waste” -that's almost the weight of a large elephant! Remember the three R’s (Reduce, Reuse, Recycle). Because credit cards are usually made from a mixture of all kinds of plastics, it’s nearly impossible for them to undergo the third R. They are perfect for Reusing, though, in some pretty amazing ways as shown here! Earbud Holders: With an electric drill you can transform your old card into a crafty place to hold those iPod ear buds that tangle up in your backpack.

Guitar Picks: MTV has a green picks recycle machine that transforms expired credit cards into guitar picks! You can watch the video about the machine here. If you don’t have access to this machine, you can cut your own guitar picks out of cards with a pair of scissors.

iPhone Stand: You find yourself completely bored in an airplane, you pull out your iPhone and play a movie, but who wants to hold up an iPhone for an hour and a half? Not anyone I know! With this cool contraption that fits easily in your wallet and is completely made of used cards, you can watch any movie, leaving both of your hands to enjoy a bucket of buttery popcorn. You can find the instructions on how to make this iPhone stand here.
Plant Labels: Credit cards are made to be durable; with a good sharpie you can turn those cards into long-lasting plant labels.
Battery Card Cover: Most of us have lost at least one battery cover in our lives, whether it is for a T.V. remote, wireless-mouse cover or a remote-controlled garage door. And many of us have resorted to the cheap and ineffective method of rubber bands or duct tape. The real way to go around fixing this situation is to get an old flexible card, cut it in the shape of the battery cover and wedge it in its place. Its flexibility lets you easily take it out.
Emergency Ice Scraper: Keep an extra old card in you car in case you wake up on a cold wintry day and find your car windows covered in snow.
Grappling Hook: If you’re looking for some humor, this little devise, although it can’t be used to climb walls, can be used to snag something off your coworker’s desk. The instructions on how to make this cool device can be found here.
Construction: They are very useful for applying wall or floor filler, and for grouting tiled walls.
Cable Organizer: Your credit card was used to buy you that TV, computer, and stereo system in your living room, andyour credit card can also organize the cords that give power to these objects. To make this organizer, cut holes a bit larger than each cable that you want to fit in each hole, then cut a line from that hole, towards the outside of the card to help you put the cable in the card. For larger and heavier cables, glue multiple cards together to add more support.
Shoehorn: If you cut them up a little at the ends, they can act as a great tool to help you put your shoes on.
